place.name: PENNARD
place.gazetteerText: PENNARD, or Pennarth, a parish in Swansea district, Glamorgan; on the E side of Oxwich bay, 6½ miles S W by S of Swansea r. station. Post-town, Swansea. Acres, 2, 292; of which 45 are water. Real property, £2, 102; of which £150 are in quarries. Pop., 321. Houses, 65. The property is subdivided. P. Castle belongs to the Edwardian times; but is now reduced tolittle more than a bold gateway, with rude flankingtowers. The coast has been much dis integrated by these a; and now has extensive sands where formerly therewas good land. There is a coast-guard station. The living is a vicarage in the diocese of St. Davids. Value, £79. Patron, T. Penrice, Esq. The present church is good; and a former church is represented by some tracesamong the sands. (In 1870-72, John Marius Wilson's Imperial Gazetteer of England and Wales)
